awd_titl_txt: CPS: Medium: Detecting and Controlling Unwanted Data Flows in the Internet of Things
awd_abstract_narration:
Many emerging Internet-connected devices are not personal computers. They are special-purpose commodity consumer electronic devices such as, for example, smart thermostats and smart door locks. Collectively, these devices are known as the Internet of Things (IoT).  They are increasingly used in smart homes, smart cities, intelligent transportation systems, industrial networks and more. The promise of IoT is to improve the quality of everyday life and make society more productive.

IoT devices however are not without technological and societal risk.  The technological risk derives in part from software and security vulnerabilities.  The vast diversity and number of IoT devices make overall consistency problematic and contribute to various inefficiencies. There are risks over the life cycle of some deployed IoT devices that their software may never be patched and their hardware never repaired; i.e., these devices will effectively remain vulnerable indefinitely.  The societal risk derives in part from the massive data that is now possible to collect using IoT devices from most anywhere, which violate privacy norms. Moreover, compromised IoT devices might serve as a large-scale highly distributed platform to flood the Internet, disrupting many vital services for society.

This project develops technologies that ensure that IoT deployments remain secure and protect user privacy in the face of the widespread deployment of connected smart devices. Network-based defenses against common attacks and device owners' ability to inspect, audit, control and share data are essential capabilities to mitigating technological and societal risks.  This project focuses: (1) protecting the devices from vulnerabilities that are often introduced through the use of untrusted software libraries, (2) detecting when devices exhibit anomalous behavior that would suggest an unauthorized data leak or device compromise, relying on statistical anomaly detection of network traffic patterns, and (3) controlling unwanted data leaks and attacks in the network using network firewall rules, outputs from these anomaly detection systems, and software systems that let the owners of these devices inspect and determine the data sent and received.  This project advances the theory and practice of network traffic analysis, anomaly detection, and secure segmentation of networks that ensure IoT deployments remain secure despite insecure connected devices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many emerging Internet-connected devices are not personal computers, but rather are special-purposes devices with Internet connectivity. Examples of these devices include thermostats, smart plugs, connected cameras, and a variety of consumer electronics. This class of devices, which has generally been referred to as the Internet of Things (IoT), has seen deployments in smart homes, enterprise and industrial networks, and smart and connected cities. IoT promises to improve transportation, reduce crime, improve citizen health, and gather better data about where to make investments or devote limited resources. As such IoT devices proliferate, however, so too do the privacy and security risks. Many IoT devices have shipped with serious security vulnerabilities; in many of these cases, device manufacturers have been slow to update vulnerable software or firmware. Because IoT systems typically provide insufficient means for device-level control or management, insufficient system updates or configurations may occur post-deployment.

This project developed defenses, both system-based and algorithmic, to ensure the security and privacy of IoT devices in smart and connected communities in spite of the poor security and privacy practices of the device vendors themselves. This project developed mechanisms that allow the operators of these devices in smart homes, municipalities, enterprises, and industrial deployments to: (1) Protect the devices from vulnerabilities that are often introduced through the use of open-source, untrusted software libraries. (2) Detect when devices exhibit anomalous behavior that would suggest an unauthorized data leak, device compromise, or device failure, by relying on statistical anomaly detection of network traffic patterns. (3) Control unwanted data leaks and attacks in the network using network firewall rules, outputs from these anomaly detection systems, and software systems that let the owners of these devices inspect and control the traffic that these devices are sending. 

The project has resulted in several top-tier conference publications, a new course in Machine Learning for Networked Systems, a draft textbook based on the course, with worked hands-on examples, and an open-source python library, netml, which has been used by research projects, educational courses, and industry around the world.

Additionally, this project developed, evaluated, and released state of the art machine learning algorithms for outlier detection, including a new OCSVM model that speeds up outlier classification in cyber-physical system (CPS) and IoT networks by 30-40x, with dramatically reduced memory footprint. 

Finally, the project demonstrated a wide range of privacy attacks on smart-home Internet of Things devices, including smart TVs, in-home medical devices, thermostats, and other smart home devices. The project also explored the extent to which emerging IoT applications, such as voice assistants and associated "skills" can mislead users into revealing sensitive or private information. The project resulted in more than 20 publications in top-tier research conferences, produced graduate students and postdocs, many of whom are now employed as professors at top universities around the country (e.g., New York University, Colgate), and policy reports for advisory committees, including the Broadband Internet Technical Advisory Group.
